skill.name: sast-horusec
skill.description: Multi-language static application security testing using Horusec with support for 18+ programming languages and 20+ security analysis tools. Performs SAST scans, secret detection in git history, and provides vulnerability findings with severity classification. Use when: (1) Analyzing code for security vulnerabilities across multiple languages simultaneously, (2) Detecting exposed secrets and credentials in git history, (3) Integrating SAST into CI/CD pipelines for secure SDLC, (4) Performing comprehensive security analysis during development, (5) Managing false positives and prioritizing security findings.

skill.author: AgentSecOps

security_audit.summary: This skill contains only documentation and configuration templates. No executable scripts, no network calls, and no direct filesystem access. The skill guides users on how to use the Horusec CLI tool which they install separately. Pure documentation-based skill with no code execution capabilities.

content.value_statement: Manual security reviews miss common vulnerabilities. This skill provides Horusec-based SAST workflows to automatically scan code across 18+ languages, detect secrets in git history, and integrate security scanning into CI/CD pipelines for continuous protection.
actual_capabilities: Run static application security tests across 18+ programming languages
Detect exposed secrets and credentials in git history
Generate vulnerability reports with severity classification
Integrate security scanning into CI/CD pipelines
Configure false positive suppression and risk acceptance workflows
Map findings to OWASP Top 10 and CWE classifications
limitations: Does not execute scans directly - requires Horusec CLI installation
Scanner runs outside the skill context after installation
No automatic remediation of found vulnerabilities
Requires Docker or manual tool installation for full functionality

use_cases.title: Detect secrets in git history

best_practices: Run Horusec scans before every code commit to catch vulnerabilities early
Configure severity thresholds in CI/CD to fail builds on high and critical findings
Store scan results securely and restrict access to authorized security personnel only
anti_patterns: Ignoring informational findings without review - they may indicate deeper issues
Running scans only at deployment time instead of continuously during development
Committing Horusec configuration files with production credentials or sensitive data

faq.question: What languages does Horusec support?
faq.answer: Horusec supports 18+ languages including Python, Java, Go, JavaScript, TypeScript, Ruby, Kotlin, C#, PHP, C, HTML, JSON, Dart, Elixir, Shell, Terraform, Kubernetes, and Nginx.

faq.question: How do I install Horusec?
faq.answer: Install via Docker (recommended): docker run -v $(pwd):/src horuszup/horusec-cli:latest horusec start -p /src. Or install CLI directly via brew, curl, or download from GitHub releases.

faq.question: Does Horusec modify my source code?
faq.answer: No, Horusec only reads and analyzes your code. It does not modify any files. Configuration files are created separately in .horusec/ directory.

faq.question: Can I use Horusec offline?
faq.answer: Yes, Horusec can run offline after initial Docker image download. No network calls are made during analysis. Ensure images are pulled before air-gapped usage.

faq.question: How do I reduce false positives?
faq.answer: Create .horusec/config.json with horusecCliFalsePositiveHashes and horusecCliFilesOrPathsToIgnore. Exclude test directories, vendor folders, and known false positive patterns.

faq.question: How does Horusec compare to other SAST tools?
faq.answer: Horusec combines 20+ security tools into one interface, supporting more languages than most single-tool solutions. It provides unified reporting across all integrated scanners.
